now right here you can really get a good look at what I was talking about about
the inside of the mouth just the same techniques I did on the

that carapace so just a similar type of technique when I created the mouth I

mouth so vicious vicious looking but as the clay dries the holes will kind of
close up a little bit so to expand the holes I'm just gonna use this hand drill
and kind of open those holes up a little bit so that the teeth are easier to
insert this is going to be an interesting technique I'm gonna use this
modeling paste and I'm gonna apply it to the model and the reason I'm using the
modeling paste and not I didn't sculpt all this in to begin with was because
well one you have a limited time to sculpt this stuff and two it's the stuff
it doesn't hold detail spectacularly well it will you know you can sculpt
some detail in it but it's hard to get like little minut details and I thought
that I could use the modeling paste and drag it out and get those folds of the
skin that look really nice and just super easy I'm also going to work it
around where the little crawler legs are gonna pop out so it look like folds of
skin around that area where the legs pop out if you've never used this stuff
before it's great I use it all the time on models for details like this and it
dries hard but a little bit flexible it paints well because it's actually for
paintings you put it on paintings to add texture to paintings and it works great
and look how nice that is now I need to make the scores of teeth I
need for this beastie because there are a lot of teeth holes in his mouth and I
need teeth so I'm just rolling the clay between my fingers getting it to a point
making some of them different sizes but roughly the same shape and size I'm just
going to a ton of these for the teeth now one nice attribute of the cold
porcelain is it's it's kind of translucent not totally translucent but
it gives a nice translucency that looks like teeth or bone actually so I really
like the effect that that gives another thing I'm going to do is make the little
crawler leg so it's just kind of a almost a tube with a claw on the end and
the great thing about this cold porcelain is this really tough if you
were doing with this with sculpey it would and you'd knock this over the
claws and everything would break off no question even if you had to wire in them
they would break off but the cold porcelain you could actually drop it or
knock it over and the claws may not break they probably wouldn't break
because the stuff is so super hard that's one great another great quality
to this cold porcelain so I just need to make enough of these crawler legs that
will run up the body length of the body and this is really gonna make it look
different from my other purple worm first order of business is to glue those
crawler legs in and I'm using my e6000 a great glue for if you want something to
stay put here it is with all the crawler legs glued on and I'll just let that dry
now I want some weight for the bottom of the worm because I'm gonna put it on a
base and I want it to stand up and not fall over so I'm using these washers as
weight on the bottom of the worm I'm just going to add some e6000 to these
and glue them all together just gonna rip my worm from its temporary cardboard
base after the washers all dry I've got to glue them to the base of the worm
with my e6000 you can see those have some good weight
the worm is actually just standing up on those washers after it dries of course I
love these little crawler legs they really make the thing look creepy and
that's a nice difference from my other purple worm I really love the mouth too
it's a really big divergence from what I did the first time with the purple worm

where I'm doing it so sound so good though
so I'm gonna kind of match it up with the edge of the base so it doesn't go

and I'll just enhance some areas where the cracks are
and we'll just let this dry overnight and we'll be good
my white porcelain is all hardened and I'm gonna use this Elmer's glue-all to
add sand to the base I really like to use the sand that has mixed aggregate
which means it's not just place and it has small pebbles and that kind of thing
and it really gives a nice appearance of a varied you know earth texture so I'm
just gonna add some Elmer's glue to the base just pour the sand over it and get
a really nice earth texture on there once that dries I am ready to paint this
beastie so we're moving into the final stages so you can see I have
spray-painted this flat black it's nice because I'll take the paint easier and
I'm gonna start out with a very dark purple this will be kind of my base coat
for this beastie you notice I'm not painting the hard carapace the same
color I'm going to paint it a different color
I painted the interior of the mouth with a nice cherry red I can't wait till we
get all those teeth in there I'm gonna give the base a nice coat of dark brown
and that'll be to start now I'm going to use a lighter shade of purple and dry
brush some areas in particular the folds of skin and the segmentations on the
front belly and I'm just kind of dry brushing these areas if you're not
familiar with that it's putting a little bit of paint on the brush and then
dragging it over the surface to pick out the details you can see as you apply
this light or coat all those little details you sculpt it and start to pop
out I wanted to do something interesting for the carapace so what I'm doing is
I'm using this plaid color shifting purple and you can see how the color
shifts when I put it on the model itself so I'm gonna paint the carapace with
this interesting color in the next step I hit the worm with a
dark wash right and so what I'm doing in here is kind of building layers of color
and darkness and shade right I decided to use this berry color for the inside
of the mouth the next step I decided to do is put the teeth in and it's a bit
tricky I have to glue each tooth individually into the cavity that I made
in the mouth you know you can easily bump another tooth and get it out of
place so you've got to you know continually adjust and everything so
it's a bit tricky getting your hands in there but the end result is going to be
so fantastic and I love that the tooth looked like bone you know they look like
real teeth with this cold porcelain I love it and you can see here you know
when we've got the teeth in how fantastic that really looks I decided
when I got all the tooth in and they were dry that I was going to use a
little bit of brown ink and I'll paint the base of the teeth and that'll give
them kind of a weathered look and I like to paint near where they go into the gum
of the mouth so it's kind of like you know worn more on the ends and browned
near the gum and I think it's a nice effect it's a really nice effect it's
really easy to do just have a gentle hand you know and get around the base of
each tooth but I think the you know the maw with these teeth and it is just
fantastic I love this effect I love the look and it's definitely very different
from my first purple worm you know how you'll do something that's
not quite how you expected well the carapace was not quite how I
wanted it with the color changing paint so I decided to go to a bone white and
I'm going to dry brush that on there but you don't lose that work that you did
earlier because you've got those layers of color in there and they kind of shine
through you know come through the cracks and crevices of this carapace so it's
not waste at work you're just kind of building on the previous work never
think of it as just wasting your work think of it as you know building layers
of color and interest right since this is a purple worm I wasn't
really happy with the bone look right I want this to be a purple worm so what I
did is use some ink and give it a nice wash on that bone color
and you still get the lightness of the bone and it's kind of coming through but
you also get that nice kind of color wash on there that gives it that tint of
the purple color which I think really works for the purple worm
I also did a bit more a light purple dry brushing on the belly to kind of bring
it out when I did the wash I've made everything very dark so I gave it
another layer of dry brushing to bring out those details another aspect I
thought might be fun that I didn't do on my first purple worm was kind of slob or
hanging down right and of course I turned my glue gun to do that so I'm
gonna use parchment paper and drag it over the surface and get little strips
of clear you know the clear glue and I can glue those to the inside of the
mouth and it'll look like it's hanging down so cool so I could have stopped
right there and been done but I decided I want to add a couple more things
because one of the challenges of being an artist is knowing when to stop you
know how far should you go to add more and then you know when you get to that
point stop but I felt that it was missing a few things and one of the
things was I wanted more earth on the worm so I decided to use my texture
paste and kind of scoop it on the worm there and do various spots especially on
top near the where the head is because that would seem to hold the most dirt as
a burst through the ground as opposed to the body that's vertical and would fall
off so I put clumps of texture paste on there and then literally just stuck my
irregular sand which is just sand with different aggregate in it into the
texture paste and that was a nice way to get the sand it's a stick as opposed to
like glue where it might just keep falling off right I'm going to use these
mud pace and they're really cool because they have actual grit in them so it's
not just a color it's texture too after the sand and Benin texture paste
dried I paint it the same color as the base and then added those different mud
colors to get a nice effect and you can see how nice that looks on there I'm
really glad I went this extra step and finally down to the last thing right I
wanted to make the inside the mouth look glossy as well as the slobber strands so
I use this plant gloss and it's water base which is nice because it's just
